--- title: On the gravitational nature of time ignore_parsers: - tags id: onTheGravitationalNatureOfTime --- ***Thank you!*** I was living in my car for 3 years and 4 months while working on this model, and I'm typing this now from a homeless shelter. This model is too important to pass by, and I'm thankful that you're open minded enough to consider the possibilities. I've tried the academic approach previously, so now I'm just going to assume that everybody reading this has zero knowledge of relativity and walk you all the way through to understanding the flaws in our current interpretations and the solutions that I am proposing. Keep an open mind, think about the concepts deeply, and by the end of this I hope that some of you will see the Universe in a new light. This may be long, but it's worth the read. **For the physics students/professionals:** It's relativistic simultaneity. Resolving this absurdity while still allowing for the experimental validations of both SR and GR gives a single possible solution to the $d=vt \gamma$ equivalence, with this solution providing a set of 3 equations yielding both our cosmological and kinematic velocities from local gravitational parameters alone to within 0.5% of direct observation, and a _possible_ relationship to $\phi$ as a dimensionless rate of spatial dilation. If you already have a solid grasp of traditional models of relativity you may want to start at the end where a simple thought experiment is given to demonstrate the case for classical simultaneity. If classical simultaneity is true while $\gamma$ is applied to the $d=vt\gamma$ equivalence, the model being proposed is the only possible mathematical solution. ## Some Prerequisite Knowledge ### Special Relativity & Time Dilation First, let's break down the difference between the generalized and specialized theories of relativity. This requires an understanding of a few concepts, but I promise, if you passed high school algebra you can follow the remainder of this note. Some calculus does make an appearance, but the concepts are what matters... not your ability to do the actual math. Special relativity refers to a set of phenomena that occur due to relative motion and the (_kind of_) fact that the speed of light is constant in all reference frames. General relativity has to do with the addition of gravity to this model through a theory known as the [equivalence principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Equivalence_principle). The equivalence principle simply put states that there is no measurable difference between being in a gravitational field that accelerates an observer at $n$ meters per second, and being in a completely gravity-free environment while in an elevator accelerating upwards at $n$ meters per second. If the magnitude is the same, gravity simply _is_ this acceleration. Next, let's break down why exactly the speed of light is presumed to be constant so we can later dissect this claim in more detail. Spoiler: _It's only half true._ $$ \begin{align} c = \frac{1}{\sqrt{\mu_0 \epsilon_0}} \end{align} $$ Here, $c$ represents the speed of light, $\mu_0$ the magnetic constant, and $\epsilon_0$ the electric constant. The magnetic and electric constants are often referred to as the permeability and permittivity of free space, respectively. Both of these _'constants'_ act as a scalar of the electric and magnetic forces, but more importantly, both have units proportional to length. $$ \begin{align} \epsilon_0 = \left[ \frac{F}{m} \right] \qquad \mu_0 = \left[ \frac{H}{m} \right] \end{align} $$ Where $F$ is a _Farad_, $H$ is a _Henry_, and $m$ is a meter. The square brackets are used only to imply the equality is demonstrating units. > The fact that both of these _constants_ have units proportional to length will become important soon. Consider taking some time to think about how the geometry of these units relates to the equivalence principle and cosmic inflation. #### Time dilation due to relative motion Einstein was famous for quite a few incredible discoveries, and he deserves credit for even the one which I am attempting to disprove. I am not proposing that his theory was completely wrong. In fact it was far, far closer to the truth than any of his contemporaries, but his insistence on a static Universe (a Universe that is not expanding) early in his career led him to miss the obvious. Throughout the remainder of this note I will attempt to help you see the mistake that he made, but first, we must cover what he did right. The next few paragraphs will walk you through a derivation that follows the derivation provided by Einstein himself to the best of my ability without going into the details of the Maxwell equations, electromagnetism and vector calculus. Imagine shooting a laser straight up and down from the floor of some spaceship. Thinking of this as being in a spaceship is important for it's lack of gravitational field. This will become incredibly important as we move forward and integrate gravity into this model. At some height $h$ above that laser, place a mirror, and another mirror where the laser is placed (this isn't technically possible because the laser would be occupying that space. Pretend that the laser is like a ghost for the sake of this thought experiment). At the end of this thought experiment we should have a pair of mirrors with a laser bouncing between them, straight up and down. Imagine that each unit of time, $t$, occurs over the period that a photon is in transit between one mirror and the other. There's nothing truly special about the speed of light directly. What matters is the speed of causality, the ability for one event at some position $\left( x_{0},\ y_{0},\ z_{0},\ t_{0} \right)$ to affect an object or an observer at another position, $\left( x_{1},\ y_{1},\ z_{1},\ t_{1} \right)$. Since $c$, the speed of light is the fastest possible way for us to become aware of some distant event, $c$ is _equivalent_ to the speed of causality. **This** is why time appears to dilate due to the constant nature of the speed of light, but is it really constant? So that 'time clock' we set up a couple paragraphs ago? Let's set that in motion now, literally. Imagine that we are now in a _different_ spaceship. All of the physics majors are likely screaming right now, waiting for me to tell you how the entire basis of relativity is that all motion is relative and that there is no such thing as absolute rest or absolute motion, but I'm here to tell you that this is wrong. In fact, this is ***not*** the way we treat motion mathematically. In reality, physics carves out a unique niche for gravity, one where all motion is calculated relative to the underlying gravitational field, so that's what we should do here: The spaceship you are in is at rest relative to the local gravitational acceleration. This is equivalent to the free fall frame from the reference frame of a body in co-motion with the 'dough', but a rest frame in the coordinate system of the 'oven' as the 'dough' dilates around the observer. Now since we're far out in outer space, far away from any stars or planets in this thought experiment we can pretend that gravitational acceleration is zero. This is a core piece of special relativity, but don't worry... we'll add gravity back in the next section. Now imagine that we are at rest in spaceship $A$, while spaceship $B$ (containing the light clock) zooms past us in a straight line and a constant speed at velocity $v$. That light clock we just made is no longer a line straight up and down, but a triangle. We can use this, the _'constant'_ speed of light, and the Pythagorean theorem to find: $$ \begin{align} t_{\prime}^2 v^2 + t^2 c^2 & = t_{\prime}^2 c^2 \\ \frac{v^2}{c^2} + \frac{t^2}{t_{\prime}^2} & = 1 \\ \frac{t^2}{t_{\prime}^2} & = 1 - \frac{v^2}{c^2} \\ t_{\prime} & = t \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - \frac{v^2}{c^2}}} \end{align} $$ This factor of $1/\sqrt{1-v^2/c^2}$ is such an important part of relativity that it gets it's own symbol, $\gamma$ (_gamma_). And that's it! You've successfully derived time dilation due to relative motion, or did you? That's what modern physics would tell us, although many pompous academics would take issue with the simplistic derivation, but let's break down what we ***actually*** discovered here. First, we have the emission of the photon from the 'laser'. Let's say that this event occurred at $\left( x_{0},\ y_{0},\ z_{0},\ t_{0} \right)$. We then have the second event, let's say at $\left( x_{1},\ y_{1},\ z_{1},\ t_{1} \right)$. Time dilation is only 1 possible solution here. What we have really discovered is the Euclidean distance between these two events is elongated by an additional factor of $\gamma$. $$ \begin{align} \text{distance} = \text{velocity}\cdot \text{time} \cdot \gamma \end{align} $$ So we are left with two possible solutions: 1. Time, a quantity we have never directly measured, and a quantity we aren't even sure exists in any physically meaningful manner dilates. 2. Space dilates with time. This coincides perfectly with the notion of cosmic inflation (the expansion that gives us the Big Bang model), and as you will soon see, allows us to collapse cosmic inflation, gravitational acceleration and time itself into a single process as observed from different reference frames. Some units have to change to modify quantities that are proportional to time, making them instead proportional to motion or other processes that are currently proportional to time, but all experiments validating current models of relativity are satisfied due to the $d=vt\gamma$ equivalence that both models seek to maintain. To be clear, what I am proposing is that time doesn't dilate with relative motion. In fact, I'm claiming that time doesn't exist at all, that time exists only as a ratio of distances. In turn, many of the attributes currently attributed to time become attributed to motion, making motion the 4th fundamental rate of change (just as is indicated in $\gamma$ where $t$ is a function of $v$). If the collective motion in the coordinate system of the 'oven' for all bodies within the Universe equals zero, the passage of time ceases. Due to our co-motion across the temporal (time) axis we don't perceive this dilation of distance directly, but we _do_ experience this dilation as gravitational acceleration. So on that note, let's add gravity back into this equation. ### General Relativity & New physics > **Beware:** Calculus... but not much In this section we will attempt to demonstrate the equivalence principle and the relationship this principle has to the model I'm proposing. In short, we can derive a dilation of space that is of the precise magnitude required to produce our local gravitational acceleration. From this derivation we can substitute this equation for $\gamma$ as it represents the same phenomenon in a different reference frame, solve that equation for velocity, and what do you know... it matches direct observation with an error margin of less than 0.5%! This works because the dilation of space due to relative motion ***is*** gravity. So far we've only reviewed what Einstein himself gave us. His brilliance in finding the additional factor of $\gamma$ in the simple $d=vt\gamma$ equivalence gives us the opportunity to derive our velocity here on Earth in two distinct forms, but first we must discuss how a single body can have two different velocities. To dive deeper into the relationship between cosmic inflation, gravitational acceleration and time let us use some common analogies. The most common analogy you're likely to hear for cosmic inflation is that of a loaf of raisin bread or a blueberry muffin. If we imagine a piece of dough placed into an oven, each blueberry will move away from the center of the dough at a velocity that is proportional to the distance that the blueberry was from the center when the dough was placed into the oven. If the berry started further from the center, it will move away from the center faster as all of the dough in between the berry and the center of the dough expands. This concept gives us our notion of _cosmological velocity_: Our velocity that takes into account this dilation of space. In this notion of velocity, it is not the motion of the berry _through_ the dough that matters alone, but rather the cumulative motion of both the berry's motion through the dough and the motion of the dough itself. Our _kinematic velocity_ is different, being made of only the motion _through_ the dough. #### Cosmological Velocity First, let's start with our cosmological velocity. The following is our standard equation for gravity $$ \begin{align} \vec{g} = G \frac{M \cancel{m}}{R^2} \hat{R} \end{align} $$ Here I am crossing out the second factor of mass. Because of the manner that this equation is applied in standard physics, this second mass is cancelled and the equation becomes as if the second object is not directly affected by the dilation of space around the primary object. This of course becomes reciprocal, giving rise to a gravitational field of apparent acceleration while the secondary object remains at rest relative to the 'oven'. It is my position that this additional factor of mass helps to hide the true nature of gravity, and that applying this factor that ends up being cancelled anyways is flawed. This does not effect the math at all, but it _does_ effect the physics. Above, $\vec{g}$ is the acceleration due to gravity, $G$ is the gravitational constant, $M$ is the mass of the gravitational source, $R$ is the distance from the center of mass of the gravitational source, and $\hat{R}$ just gives the acceleration a direction. If we then take the derivative (break things into really, really small pieces) of this equation with respect to radius[^5] we find $$ \begin{align} \delta = 2 G \frac{M_{\oplus}}{R_{\oplus}^3}\hat{R} \end{align} $$ Above, $\oplus$ indicates that a value pertains specifically to Earth, and $\delta$ (_delta_) is an arbitrary variable used for this equation elsewhere. By taking the derivative of this equation we've found another equation that when integrated (adding up all of the really, really small pieces) we get an acceleration of gravity that matches precisely with what we experience. We're getting closer, but as $\gamma$ is applied as a scalar, we should take the average of the integral of this equation. If you're unfamiliar with calculus, we are adding up all of the small changes in distance that would occur according to the model being proposed, and taking the average of the sum of all of these small changes to give us a scalar that we can apply to distance in a way that is symmetric with the manner in which $\gamma$ is applied. This allows us to essentially exchange the two variables as they describe the same phenomenon in a different reference frame, and can now both be applied as scalars. The average of this integral gives us: $$ \begin{align} \xi = \frac{1}{R} \int 2 G \frac{M_{\oplus}}{R_{\oplus}^3}\ dR = 1 + G \frac{M_{\oplus}}{R^3_{\oplus}} = 1 + \frac{g}{R_{\oplus}} \end{align} $$ This means that we can now solve $\gamma$ for $v$ to find $$ \begin{align} v_{\omega} = \sqrt{c - \frac{1}{\gamma}} \end{align} $$ And since $\xi \equiv \gamma$, we can substitute: $$ \begin{align} v_{\omega} = \sqrt{c - \frac{1}{\xi}} \Rightarrow \sqrt{c - \frac{1}{\left( 1 + G \frac{M_{\oplus}}{R_{\oplus}^3} \right)^2}} = 528.142 \ \frac{\text{km}}{\text{sec}} \end{align} $$ The above value falls almost perfectly on top of probability curves found through direct observation, but we're not done! We can derive our kinematic velocity too.
Image demonstrating the consistency of this value with observation. Taken from Gordon & Land
#### Kinematic Velocity Before we dive into the derivation for the kinematic velocity we first need to dig a little deeper into the muffin analogy. Imagine the muffin baking in the oven. If there was some coordinate system in the oven, and a coordinate system in the muffin, there is exactly 1 position within the muffin that does not move relative to the oven as the dough expands, assuming that the 'muffin' is not in motion with respect to the oven along any of the three spatial dimensions. If we expand that analogy to our Universe, we will call that point $p_{\alpha}$... essentially $$ p_{\alpha} = \left( x_{\alpha},\ y_{\alpha},\ z_{\alpha},\ t_{\alpha} \right) = \left( 0,\ 0,\ 0,\ 0 \right) $$ This point $p_{\alpha}$ now would be expanded to contain the entire Universe as the Big Bang model describes, but there is one key difference in the model I am proposing: This point exists concurrently to our own, separated only by some deviation across this density axis. In other words, the 'dough' started out as the ultra-dense early Universe that gives us the Big Bang model, but that 'dough' will be the size of the Universe at which ever time is in question. The 'dough' ***is*** the Universe, but unlike our analogy, the existence of different density states is concurrent, giving us a _real_ Euclidean distance to this point. This concurrent nature of time should be pretty self evident, even in existing models of relativity and, I argue, has been demonstrated [experimentally](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hafele%E2%80%93Keating_experiment). Consider two observers, $O_{a}$ and $O_{b}$. If $O_{a}$ and $O_{b}$ are initially very near one another so that they come close to sharing the same coordinates, $O_{a}$ and $O_{b}$ would exist at a shared time coordinate. If $O_{b}$ however was to be set into motion, $\gamma$ is applied, making it so that $O_{b}$ has progressed further along the time axis than $O_{a}$. While both existed once at a shared position along our temporal axis, they now exist concurrently at different time coordinates. If we modify the equations above so we instead define $g$ not as proportional to time, but as proportional to motion _through_ space we reach the cusp of the model I'm proposing: Motion occupies the 4th fundamental rate of change, ***not*** time. That is to say that for some small motion _through_ the 'dough', the 'dough' dilates by some small quantity that is a function of that motion _through_ the 'dough'. The faster (greater magnitude since there is no concept of time anymore) an object moves _through_ the dough, the faster the dough dilates. So let us slightly modify the equation for our cosmological velocity to take into account this proportionality to motion, removing the dependence on time. This in turn removes the expansion of the 'dough', giving us our kinematic velocity. First though, we must define a 'time equivalent' quantity, since we are removing time from the equation. **Time equivalent quantities:** $\dot{x}$ does not indicate a time derivative in the traditional sense. Instead, it indicates a ***fundamental*** change in displacement. This occupies the role that time previously held as a driving rate of change instead of a rate of change that is proportional to another. In the model being proposed _motion_ occupies this 4th fundamental rate of change, while the 4th temporal coordinate is indicated by a coordinate along the spatial density axis this model demonstrates. Not only is time an emergent quantity, it's an emergent axis that arises from the dilation of space induced by motion along the 3 spatial dimensions. To demonstrate this equivalence, let's consider the proposed $\xi$. Since $\xi$ and $\gamma$ represent the same process in different reference frames, lets set them to be equivalent. $$ \begin{align} \xi & = \gamma \end{align} $$ $$ \begin{align} \left( 1 + \frac{g}{R} \right)^{2} \left( 1 - \beta^{2} \right) & = 1 \end{align} $$ Expanding this gives: $$ \begin{align} 2 G \frac{M}{R^{3}} + G^{2} \frac{M^{2}}{R^{6}} = \beta^{2} + 2 G \frac{M}{R^{3}} \beta^{2} + G^{2} \frac{M^{2}}{R^{6}} \beta^{2} \end{align} $$ Or: $$ \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{GM \left( GM + 2R^{3} \right)}}{GM + R^{3}} = \frac{v}{c} \end{align} $$ And if we solve this for $v$, we recover our cosmological velocity times a function: $$ \begin{align} v = \Gamma c \frac{\sqrt{GM \left( GM + 2R^{3} \right)}}{GM + R^{3}} = c \sqrt{1 - \frac{1}{(1 + \frac{g}{R})^{2}}} \end{align} $$ Where $\Gamma$ is: $$ \begin{align} \frac{\sqrt{G M \left(G M + 2 R^{3}\right)}}{\sqrt{\frac{- R^{6} + \left(G M + R^{3}\right)^{2}}{\left(G M + R^{3}\right)^{2}}} \left(G M + R^{3}\right)} = 0.99999999999512 \end{align} $$ In other words, $\xi \approx \gamma$ when $v = v_{\omega}$, with all quantities being consistent with observation and apparently indicative of a near-equilibrium state. If the 'dough' dilates as a function of the magnitude of a body's motion _through_ the 'dough', and this process when summed over for all bodies within the Universe gives us cosmic inflation, there is no need for some abstract quantity we naively call time. We can define time purely as a ratio of these distances... the distance a body travels _through_ the dough, and a distance that two nearby points diverge from each other. To be more precise, our temporal coordinate is a position along this density axis. This ratio is what gives us the perceived acceleration due to gravity, cosmic inflation, and the perceived passage of time. When $ds/dx$ is greater than 1 we produce what we now consider a blackhole, however these blackholes are nothing more than a mirage in the distance that dissipates as an observer approaches that gravitational field, dilating $c$ proportionally to $\sum \xi$.[^3] In it's integral (adding up all of the small changes) form, this might look like: $$ \begin{align} \Delta \tau = \frac{\int_p \dot{x}}{\int \dot{x}} \end{align} $$ This notation is likely confusing, so let me explain. The denominator indicates the change in displacement integrated over a single unit of "time", giving a measure of length equivalent to the velocity in units of length, while the subscript $p$ indicates an integral that continues to grow as the Universe progress temporally. To put this in human language, there is no time anymore. There is only motion _through_ the "dough", and motion _of_ the "dough". When each small motion _through_ the "dough" is added up over all of the time in question, we get $\int_p \dot{x}$. This number will be proportional to time in our standard units of measure, but there is no need for time in the physical sense. Our attribution of time is largely arbitrary, albeit proportional to the rate of cosmic inflation as we currently define cosmic inflation as being proportional to time. This relationship of course becomes inverse, but this is irrelevant as $ds/dt = 1$ locally. The difference between local and non-local spatial dilation is what gives rise to the ***observable*** cosmic inflation and the Hubble parameter. Since the dilation of space _is_ time, this ratio will always be 1, making the inverse of this relationship irrelevant. This is precisely why gravity lacks any apparent [aberration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aberration_(astronomy)), why the dilation of space remains hidden from us due to our co-motion along this density axis, and why Earth, being in a near equilibrium position produces an excess dilation of space at the poles due to the lack of centripetal force that precisely cancels out the excess dilation of space due to motion at the equator. **Time Derivative Equivalent:** Consider that for $\int \dot{x}$ as it appears in equation above, $1$ unit of _pseudo-time_ will pass. Because the passage of pseudo-time is _defined_ by the relationship between proportional derivatives and distances, where $t_{p}$ indicates 1 unit of pseudo-time in units applied to the traditional notion of velocity, we can easily infer the following: $$ \begin{align} \tau_o = \frac{1 ~ t_{p}}{dt_p} \equiv \frac{\int \dot{x}_\sigma}{dx_\sigma} \end{align} $$ This gives $\tau_o$ time derivatives per unit of time, but more importantly, a time derivative, $1/\tau_o$ that is proportional to $dx$ if $\int x$ is defined by $dx$. To put this simply, we can derive an exactly proportional time-equivalent derivative so that we can remove time, and in turn cosmic inflation from the cosmological velocity derivation above. **Applying the time equivalent quantities to find our kinematic velocity:** If $\delta$ is the dilation of space in it's derivative form, let's apply the time equivalent derivative to this equation. This will make this equation proportional to motion, not time, in turn removing the motion which is only secondary to the dilation of space leaving us with only the motion that is relative to the spatial system local to the observer. Since $\delta$ in traditional models is proportional to time, $\delta$ in it's current form represents the dilation of a small quantity of space over a single unit of time, whatever the unit of time applied to $\delta$ may be.[^4] Since $v$ is also proportional to a single unit of "time", we can find a proportional value of $$ \begin{align} \delta^\prime = 2 G \frac{M_{\oplus}}{R_{\oplus}^3} \frac{1}{v} \tau \end{align} $$ When we then integrate this in the same manner in which we did to find the replacement for $\gamma$, we will now have to integrate twice. First over a unit of pseudo-time, and then over the radius. This gives us the sum of the dilation of space for each small quantity of space, for the sum of each small quantity in time, in the coordinate system of the 'dough'. $$ \begin{align} \delta_\alpha & = \frac{1}{R_{\oplus}} \int \int_0^{R} \left[ 2 G \frac{M_{\oplus}}{R_{\oplus}^{3}} \frac{1}{v_{0}} \tau \right] ~ dR\ d\tau \\ & = 1 + \frac{1}{2} G\frac{M_{\oplus}}{R_{\oplus}^3} = 371.4 ~ \text{km} ~ \text{s}^{-1} \end{align} $$ Our observed velocity relative to the [CMB](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosmic_microwave_background) (the _dough_ in this model) is approximately $370 ~ \text{km}\ \text{s}^{-1}$, and some gravitational _"turbulence"_ would be expected to give a reasonable margin of error. For the math types out there, it is important to note that the integral of $\tau$ is treated uniquely, as the denominator of $\tau$ remains fixed in the same manner as when $\tau$ was first defined. This is consistent with the nature of this model and this quantity, as this model concludes that we've had an additional derivative in our model that is not an inherent part of the system. This maintains $\tau$ as a quantity that is equivalent to time, both in integral and derivative form, and allows that certain quantities remain directly hidden from us as our co-motion along this temporal axis causes our measuring apparatus to dilate along with the objects which we are attempting to measure. This is not some mathematical bandaid, but rather a remedy to an additional derivative we've arbitrarily added to the equation that is not an inherent part of the Universe: time. ## Supportive Observations & Related Phenomena ### Pound & Rebka The [Pound-Rebka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pound%E2%80%93Rebka_experiment) experiment was an experiment carried out at Harvard in which researchers setup a light clock, not too dissimilar from the one we've setup in our previous thought experiment. The difference (at least the difference that matters) is that they moved the two 'mirrors' apart from each other at a velocity that would perfectly cancel out the [Doppler shift](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doppler_effect) induced by gravity. They found a result of $$ \begin{align} v \approx g \frac{h}{c} \end{align} $$ And because $t = d/v$ $$ \begin{align} v \approx g \Delta t \end{align} $$ If you're unfamiliar, $\Delta$ (_delta,_ I know, we've already used delta) just means the 'change of' $t$, and $h$ is the height between the emitter and the receiver. And you've likely guessed it, this coincides _perfectly_ with the outcome we would expect in the model in which $h$ dilates according to our motion through space which in turn gives the dilation of space and the passage of time, and we did so without the need to dilate a quantity that we can't even measure! Further, since both $h$ and $c$ would dilate proportionally to $\xi$ in the model being proposed, it is irrelevant which coordinate system we use to calculate $\Delta t$ as both are equivalent. In fact $d/v$ remains constant between reference frames much in the same manner that 4-vectors remained constant in traditional models of relativity. This ironically makes time the only quantity that _doesn't_ dilate proportionally to $\gamma$, as $d$ dilates in one reference frame and $v$ in the other. This maintains a consistent energy expenditure per unit length according to the underlying spatial density, strongly suggesting a sort of quantifiable empty space with which the fundamental mechanisms giving inertia lie. ### Bullet Cluster > The bullet cluster is a pair of galaxy clusters rapidly approaching each other. The extreme relative velocities accompanied by the extreme masses of each galaxy cluster give rise to a phenomenon that current models of relativity can't explain: The mass we see does not align with the gravitational lens.
Image hosted by [Caltech](https://ned.ipac.caltech.edu/level5/March15/Roos/Roos15.html). As if it's not obvious, they have no affiliation with this app or this model.
This sort of 'washing' effect is precisely what would be expected in a model in which gravity, and in turn the gravitational lens is a function of not mass alone, but of mass and velocity. ### Lack of Gravitational Aberration The apparent lack of gravitational [aberration](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aberration_(astronomy)) seems to imply that the speed of gravity is infinite, but this can't be the case. If 'time' passes and gravity effects some distant body, it must be that either gravity does not 'move' at all, or that gravity and time are the same thing. If gravity and time are the same process when observed from the coordinate system of the 'oven', $ds/dt = 1$, regardless of the units used or any relativistic effects, and any motion of space remains hidden from our perspective in the coordinate system of the 'dough' due to our co-motion along this axis. ### Super Evolved Galaxies With the launch of the James Webb Space Telescope in 2021 we've made quite a few incredible observations that require some additional context, if not entirely new physics. One of such discoveries is that of galaxies which appear to be [too large](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41550-023-01937-7) to exist at the time at which we observe them. Because light has to travel to us, the further away an object is the further in the past it was when the light that reaches our eyes or telescope departed that object. This problem of super-evolved galaxies at a time which appears to be too early for our current $\Lambda CDM$ model is resolved by the concurrent nature of this density axis being proposed. If this axis is concurrent, there is no reason to believe that there should be any limit on the evolution of a cosmic process at any point in time. Consider that for some unit of pseudo-time $d\tau$, some photon travels $c\ d\tau$, being equivalent to one 'event'. In that same unit of pseudo-time, some body $i$ travels $v_{i}\ d\tau$, making the following true and making super-evolved galaxies at early epochs not only possible, but inevitable. $$ \begin{align} \frac{\text{Events}}{\text{Distance}} \propto \frac{c}{v_{i}} \end{align} $$ ### Fine Tuning and the Fermi Paradox This geometry opens an entirely new concurrent dimension that life may be spread across. It now becomes possible that life exists at some location, separated only by this density axis. If you're the super-natural type, this concurrent density axis might explain certain unexplained phenomena. Everything from ghosts to the propulsion and plausibility of extraterrestrial visitors becomes more likely if an object may exist at shared spatial coordinates, separated only by a density axis coordinate. This model of concurrency can be extended to preclude that in order to make an object's existence linear, all that is required is a 4-dimensional coordinate for each density state. As space itself dilating gives rise to a sort of higher-order time, our motion along this density axis gives rise to time as we experience it. That is to say that we are in motion along an axis that is in motion itself. This model of concurrency does not explicitly require that an object must follow a linear path in 3-dimensional space. While the temporal axis in this model is not orthogonal, this density axis shares many properties with our 3 spatial coordinates. There is nothing to prohibit an object from traveling backwards in time, so long as the progression of $\Psi$ (below) progresses linearly (down to the Plank scale) towards $\infty$. In other words, as the Universe expands there exists a (assumingly linear, or at least linear down to the Plank scale) density axis with $n$ possible density states. Of course $n \approx \infty$ if this axis is truly linear, but even a finite $n$ trends towards $\infty$ as the Universe expands. Each object can exist at any density state $\omega$ within ${{0<\omegacan't agree upon a velocity. If both $A$ and $B$ must agree on the time at which $B$ reaches $p_{2}$ and this time must be extended by an additional factor of $\gamma$, then the agreed upon velocity produces an elongated distance while the velocity decreases by a factor of $1/\gamma$ in the coordinate system of $A$ to accommodate a $d$ that is not elongated by $\gamma$. It's as if there exists some sort of drag induced by the more dense coordinate system, and in a manner similar to the way in which 4-vectors remain constant in traditional models of relativity, $d/v$ remains constant irrespective of coordinate system. [^1]: The metric tensor, in the way it is currently applied, appears to describe this motion due to Einstein's reliance on the equivalence principle and the addition of vectors. [^3]: See the section on the Pound & Rebka results. $c$ dilates inversely proportional to spatial density, or in other words, proportional to $\xi$ in a single body approximation such as within the vicinity of a blackhole. A fundamental piece of this model is the principle that all functions limit at their Newtonian counterpart when the reference frame is shared, once this divergent geometry is accounted for. No where is this more evident than in the "constant" nature of $c$. With $c$ being constant _in_ each reference frame, it is _impossible_ for it to be equivalent **between** reference frames when the units of measure themselves are dilating. [^4]: $s^{-2}$ in standard units. The dimensionality issue with $\dot{x} \mapsto \ddot{x}$ is discussed in the section on the conservation of energy and momentum. [^5]: For each small change in the radius, there is a dilation of space equivalent to this function.

# Quick Reference

## Syntax

### FrontMatter

Insert front matter into your note using yaml syntax seperated by 3 `---`:

```yaml
---
title: My optional note title
---
```


| Property | Description |
| -------- | ----------- |
| title | An optional string that will override the title found through the note's content if present. |
| summary | An optional summary of the note. This will be displayed along with the title in search results. |
| id | An optional id for the note that can be used for dynamic linking via the `[myLink](note:myNoteId)` syntax. |
| ignoreParsers | Used mostly for internal development, can be a list of parsers that will not be applied to the note. Valid options are a list of 'tags', 'citations', 'note_link' and/or 'dictionary'. |


### Tags 

Insert **tags** into your note using the following syntax:

```mdx title="my_tag_demo.mdx"
This is my tag [[#myTag]] called 'myTag'.
```

### Citations

The citation key must match the bibliography entry key in your bibliography. For example:

```mdx
As you can see, according to Ives & Stillwell [[cite:IvesStillwell]]...
```

Will work with the bibliography entry:

```bibtex
@article{IvesStillwell,
    author = {Herbert E. Ives and G. R. Stilwell},
    journal = {J. Opt. Soc. Am.},
    keywords = {Doppler effect; Hydrogen; Light sources; Mirrors; Optical clocks; Transverse effects},
    number = {7},
    pages = {215--226},
    publisher = {Optica Publishing Group},
    title = {An Experimental Study of the Rate of a Moving Atomic Clock},
    volume = {28},
    month = {Jul},
    year = {1938},
    url = {https://opg.optica.org/abstract.cfm?URI=josa-28-7-215},
    doi = {10.1364/JOSA.28.000215},
    abstract = {},
}                
```


### Dictionary Entries

You can insert dictionary entries in any note using the following syntax:

````mdx
```dictionary -- My Dictionary Title
This is my dictionary entry.
I can insert any mdx content I like here.
```
````

These entries will automatically collected and inserted into your user defined dictionary.

# Start Here!

> If you really want to get started and you're on a Mac, open the command palette with cmd+shift+p.

My name is Andrew, and I'm the creator of Fluster. Please take the time to look through these initial notes as they contain all of the information you need to get the most from this app, as it's pretty unique among note taking applications. On first launch, there will be the following notes:

1. **Welcome To Fluster:** This is what you're reading right now.
2. **Intro to JSX:** An introduction to the 'x' in mdx. If you're already familiar with React, feel free to delete this. If not, don't worry, you don't need to know how to write the functions, just how to call them, and the provided snippets will do most of the work for you.
3. **Quick Reference:** A quick syntax reference. 
4. **On The Gravitational Nature of Time:** Consider this a demo if you like, but this is a short summary of the model that inspired the creation of Fluster. The note assumes no further knowledge than basic calculus, and does my best to take the reader from Einstein's work to a modified model of relativity that gives a set of 3 equations providing both our kinematic and cosmological velocities to well within measurement error. The problem? Gravity becomes a respulsive force. [Avi Loeb](https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=CvQxOmwAAAAJ) couldn't get that past peer review, so here we are... re-building a note taking application for the 4th time while homeless to promote the model. Feel free to just delete this if you like, but this is the reason Fluster even exists.

## Fluster's Strategy

While in most cases user's don't care much about the architecture of the application they're using, it's relevant for Fluster. Fluster uses [mdx](https://mdxjs.com/), a superset of markdown with added support for [React](https://react.dev/) components. Fluster provides a growing list of components for you, with snippets available to help speed up typing and searchability.

Here's the thing, MDX is _really_ powerful. So powerful so, that it's difficult to replicate the functionality of MDX in Apple's native language, Swift. The logical question then is well, why not just do everything in the language that makes MDX happy, Typescript? The first public release of Fluster did, but the application became limited by it's environment. The answer, is that while Apple's support for rendering math and other complex components from a 'markdown' file is extremely limited, it's support for things like the Apple pencil, onboard AI, and other first-party features are unbeatable.

The strategy Fluster takes is simple, to give users the most functionality possible by providing both rendering methods in a single application, but this comes with some downsides. 

- It will likely be noticeable when a view is rendered in a WebView or in a native Swift view. This will be improved significantly with time, but will likely never be completely cohesive.
- Math or other mdx features may not render or render incompletely in Swift views. This means that while adding latex to titles is technically allowed, the title in Swift views will display as a raw latex string instead of the rendered latex. I'll make an attempt to support math in Swift titles in the near future, but I'm unsure of how successful it will be. The alternative is to eventually move more content, like the search results into a Webview where title's can be rendered as MDX.

It is important to note, that while your Fluster application uses a `WebView`, it does not contact any outside service and functions completely offline; we are simply rendering the MDX in a language meant for the web using code that is bundled with the application.

Fluster may never offer the buttery smooth UI of applications that focus on either hand drawn or text based notes independently, but for those that require the most from their note taking application and want an app that puts functionality over form... if you're the type to generate plots, diagrams and other rich content in your notes only to dig through them for hours, Fluster may be what you're looking for.


## Organization Inside of Fluster

As Fluster came to be first as a personal note taking application to support my pursuit of a modified model of relativity, it naturally came to support a wide range of searching, linking and navigation techniques. First, you can insert a tag directly into your note's content as described in the 'Quick Reference' note. Clicking a tag will take you to a search page with all other notes featuring that tag.

Each note can contain a block of [yaml](https://learnxinyminutes.com/yaml/) between two sets of `---` with a handful of optional properties. This block is completely optional, as are all fields within it, but it allows for the extension of the search functionality by applying either a `topic` or a `subject` to a note. See the section in the 'Quick Reference' for more information.

```mdx
---
topic: Math
subject: Calc2
---
```

Each of these `topic` or `subject` fields will be searchable via the command palette on Mac, or via the relevant tabs on iPad.

Of course there is also text and named based search as well. Fluster uses a special mdx based sorting algorithm to sort search results based on the importance of where your matches occur for text based search, returning the most significant matches first. This title and full-text based search can be accessed via the command palette on Mac, or in the navigation bar on iPad.

### Bibliography

Fluster also integrates with an internal bibliography manager (plans to read data from 3rd party platforms like Zotero in the near future), with citations that can be inserted with `[[cite:myCitationId]]`. Here, `myCitationId` must match the id of an entry in your bibliography (all entries are inserted as bibtex).

When a citation is added in this format, the citation's id is parsed with the rest of the markdown, and linked to that note so that notes can be search by bibliography entry as well.

<Admonition title="Organization Recommendations" type="info" foldable folded>
- Consider using a sort of structured format to the way you treat 'topics' and 'subjects'. Many apps include similar features, but with so many tagging methods available inside of Fluster, 'topics' and 'subjects' worked best for me when I was in research mode. Using one to group things into more broader contexts and the other to narrow things down worked great for keeping related notes nearby when I was struggling with a solution. For me this meant something like using a 'subject' of something like 'gravity' or 'electromagnetism' and a 'topic' of something like 'newtonian' or 'emergent-gravity'.
- If you don't think you'll need a bibliography, consider adding simple entries for things like websites, with whatever level of specificity you think you'll need. Adding an entry for 'wikipedia' or 'youtube' will obviously be vague enough to apply to a meaningful number of notes in your content and can apply to user's with less academic notes. You can even use the website bibliography snippet to cite specific social media channels or blogs, allowing user's to group notes by almost anything on the web.
</Admonition>
